Well, I graduated from UT/austin and am now a master's student here at the 
University of Birmingham (UK), studying Natural Computation.

It really sounds _exactly_ like what you are looking for - very 
interdisciplinary. There is alot of really good research going on at this 
school, and since about 2/3rds of the course is research based there are 
alot of good opportunities for advisors.

The course website is here:
http://www.cs.bham.ac.uk/study/postgraduate-taught/msc-nc/

Additionally, it only takes 1 year for a master's degree over here - which 
is a good thing because it does tend to be rather expensive in the UK. The 
course was designed to identify good researchers, with a strong push to 
continue on with a PhD. However, there are far fewer funding options for 
americans over here, which is why I'm most likely not going to be able to 
continue on here after this year.

They also don't require an application fee nor do they look at your GRE 
scores (which was a good thing for me :)

While there are probably better schools in the UK, there are only a very 
small number of schools that do a masters on natural computation, and I 
think B'ham is the best of those. B'ham is a really good university, and 
since its not at the very top of the pack in terms of publicity its waaaay 
more relaxed and the professors and lecturers usually have alot more time 
to see you, etc (with the possible exception of Xin Yao ... but my 
coursemate Arjun on 
this list 
could tell you more about that :).

While the course was a tad rough around the edges, this is only the 3rd 
year they've offered it, and they are still improving it. With a couple of 
minor exceptions, I've been extremely happy with the course and would 
recommend it to anyone looking for the kind of thing you seem to be 
looking for.

Feel free to email me privately or on the list if you have any more 
specific questions.

-KB-


On Wed, 2 Jun 2004, Derek James wrote:

> Hi all,
> 
> I just took the GRE last weekend, with an eye toward applying for 
> graduate school.  I don't have a strong CS background, and I'm not 
> really interested in a PhD in computer science anyway.  What I'd like 
> is an interdisciplinary PhD program, in which I would spend as much 
> time studying evolutionary biology and genetics as I would 
> programming, or psychology, or neuroscience.
> 
> UCSD looks like they've got a great program.  I'm looking at UT 
> Austin, but I think I'd have to pursue a CS degree there.  And I'm 
> looking at a couple of other schools.  I know Tyler has suggested the 
> HCI program he's in at...is it Iowa State?
> 
> But I'm curious to hear anyone else's experiences applying or 
> attending graduate schools, and I'd appreciate any advice anyone 
> could give.
> 
> I also don't mind living abroad.  I've looked a bit at schools in 
> Japan and the UK, but still don't know much.  There are a few brits 
> on this list...anyone have any advice for an international student 
> possibly interested in studying there?
> 
> Thanks,
> Derek
